author: Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg
title: Reddit Taps Time Inc. Veteran Jen Wong As Its COO
text:
0 COMMENTS Digital media veteran Jen Wong has been named Reddit’s chief operating officer effective immediately, the company said Thursday.
The move comes less than three months after she stepped down as president of digital and chief operating officer at Time Inc., the magazine publisher acquired by Meredith Corp. MDP 0.19% in late January.
At the time of her departure, Ms. Wong was the highest ranking female executive at Time Inc. Her responsibilities included The Foundry, a studio that creates branded and native content for advertisers; consumer marketing; and digital advertising for Time Inc.’s brand portfolio.
Ms. Wong, 43 years old, said in an interview she has long been a Reddit user and had discussed the possibility that Time Inc. and Reddit could work together when she was at Time Inc.
“It’s a community platform with incredible potential in terms of the way it connects people and enables intimate conversations,” she said. Her goals include increasing Reddit’s revenue, building strategic partnerships, and helping Reddit reach one billion monthly users.
In her new role, Ms. Wong is responsible for business strategy and growth. She’s based in a Reddit satellite office in lower Manhattan.
Ms. Wong, who helped Time Inc. increase its digital revenue and audience, has joined Reddit at a critical time. The social media platform that bills itself as “the front page of the internet” is betting on its ability to compete for ad revenue with Google, Facebook and Snapchat.
Reddit attracted 68.4 million multiplatform unique visitors in March in the U.S., up 24.6% compared with March 2016, according to media measurement firm comScore Inc. Research firm Alexa ranks Reddit as the sixth most visited website worldwide, and ranks it fourth in the U.S.
The company, which claims 330 million monthly global users, doesn’t report profit or revenue. Besides advertising, Reddit also generates revenue from a subscription plan called Reddit Gold that enables users to turn off ads for $3.99 a month or $29.99 annually.
Reddit is currently rolling out a desktop redesign that should be available to all viewers by early May. The company also recently introduced native mobile ads for Apple mobile devices and will extend that rollout to Android mobile devices in coming weeks. Several other new ad products are in the pipeline.
Reddit was launched in 2005 by co-founders Steve Huffman and Alexis Ohanian, and acquired the following year by Conde Nast, a unit of closely held Advance Publications Inc. Ownership was later transferred directly to Advance. Following a $200 million venture funding round in 2017, Advance’s ownership stake was reduced to less than 40% including all employee stock options.
Write to Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg at jeffrey.trachtenberg@wsj.com
